sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &applet; applet, shown in Figure 1, shows the status of the power subsystem in your laptop. To add this applet to your Panel, right click on the Panel and select Panel->Add to panel->Applet->Monitors->Battery Status Utility.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: &applet; applet requires no user input. You can, if you so desire, configure it to some degree as described below.
The figure above is shown when the laptop battery is fully charged.
The little flash over the power cord is shown when the laptop battery is recharging. It's flashing on and off until the battery is fully recharged.
When you are running your laptop on battery it will display this image.

Right-clicking on the applet brings up a menu containing the following items:
Properties
Opens the Properties dialog window.
About
Shows basic information about this applet.
Help
Displays this document.
Suspend laptop
Executes the command specified in the Properties dialog. This entry will be ghosted out if you haven't specified what command to run.

sect1.title: Customization
sect1.para: You can customize the Battstat applet somewhat by right-clicking on it and choose Properties.... This will bring up the preferences dialog window.

The properties are:
Yellow: sets the battery level where the progress bar will switch from green to yellow. Default: 40.
Orange: sets the battery level where the progress bar will switch from yellow to orange. Default: 25.
Red: sets the battery level where the progress bar will switch from orange to red. Default: 15.
The preview frame contains the battery progress bar and a draggable slider. By dragging the slider you can preview how it will look when the battery level actually changes. It doesn't affect the battery in any way.
Notify me when battery charge is low: By selecting this, a warning dialog will appear when the power falls below the value in the Red entry box.
Notify me when battery is fully re-charged: By selecting this, a dialog window will appear when the battery is fully re-charged.
Beep when either of the above is tru: If you select this, your laptop will make an audible beep when any of the two above happens.
Percentage text: If you click on this button, a font selection dialog window will appear. You can then select the font of your choice for the percentage text.
Suspend command: Whatever you enter here will be executed when you click on the Suspend laptop in the applet menu. If you clear this entry field, the Suspend laptop entry will be unselectable. For example, if you are using FreeBSD you could enter apm -z or zzz here. Before you enter anything though, first make sure that you can safely suspend your laptop by testing the command in a shell.

The properties on this page are:
Move towards top:
If you select this radio button, the battery charge level meter will drain towards the positive terminal on the battery.
Move towards bottom:
If you select this radio button, the battery charge level meter will drain towards the negative terminal on the battery.
Horizontal:
By selecting this mode the applet will have a horizontal layout. (This is the default mode).
Square:
In square mode the applet will be layout in a square formed shape.
Square:
In square mode the applet will be layout in a square formed shape.
Applet Layout:
Here you can select which parts of the applets you want to have visible.
Use the status dock:
If you enable this toggle button the applet will use the status docklet if it is available.

sect2.title: Sound
sect2.para: To enable the sound support for this applet you need have sound support enabled for GNOME. To select the samples that should be played when the battery reach certain levels right-click on the Panel and select: Programs->Settings->Multimedia->Sound. Make sure you have both the Enable sound server startup and the Sounds for events check buttons enabled. Next click on the Sound Events tab and scroll down to the Battery Status Utility field. Here you can assign samples to the different battery events.
